title: Hamilton talks anti-bullying in the wake of teen’s death
text:
Police investigating what role bullying played

A crowd of people wearing purple gathered at a high school football game in Hamilton last night to remember Devan Bracci-Selvey.

Purple was the 14-year-old’s favourite colour.

Devan died on Oct. 7 after being stabbed behind his high school, Sir Winston Churchill Secondary.

“When I found out I almost burst out crying,” said one student in an interview about Devan the day after his death.

Hundreds of people showed up at Sir Winston Churchill Secondary School on Oct. 9 to remember Devan. (Justin Mowat/CBC)

Four teens were arrested in connection with the case and two of them have been charged with first-degree murder.

The two other teens were released without charges after being questioned by police.

Even though it isn’t clear what role bullying played in Devan’s death, police say that part of their investigation is “growing.”

An anti-bullying message was also at the heart of a vigil for Devan that took place on the front lawn of his school on Oct. 9.

Anti-bullying was a big part of the conversation at a vigil and memorial football game in Devan's honour this week. (Justin Mowat/CBC)

Devan’s mom, Shari-Ann Selvey, said her son was bullied for the first time on the second day of school and it continued from there.

"For a month, we've been trying to get this dealt with," said Selvey.

The Hamilton-Wentworth District School Board (HWDSB) confirmed that school administrators had received reports that Devan was being bullied.

Manny Figueiredo, the board’s education director, said he’s waiting for police to finish their investigation before he draws any conclusions.

But he said, “I don’t believe the school failed him.”

Social workers and police officers were on site at the school this week to help students cope with the news.

At the candlelight vigil for Devan, supporters wore T-shirts with the words: “Stand up. Speak Out. Stop bullying for good.” (Cole Burston/The Canadian Press)

What should you do if you’re being bullied?

The first step is to speak out about it, said Tracy Vaillancourt, a professor at the University of Ottawa who studies bullying.

Kids often think that telling an adult will only make things worse, she said, but the research shows that’s not true.

"The problem is that kids don't trust us," Vaillancourt said. "They think we're going to screw it up and they'll always find an example … of when it did get screwed up."

In fact, she said, most research suggests that if the bullying is immediately reported and some action is taken, the torment usually stops right away.

People have left animals, flowers and candles in front of Devan’s home. His funeral is scheduled to take place on Oct. 12. (Dan Taekema/CBC)

Experts say it’s also important to step in when you see someone being bullied, as long as it’s safe to do so.

Don’t forget that Kids Help Phone is always an option. You can live chat, text or call the counselling service any time.

With files from Dan Taekema and Justin Mowat
description: Anti-bullying messages abound as Hamilton police investigate what role bullying played in the death of 14-year-old Devan Bracci-Selvey.
